notes.text: The preposition onto written as one word (instead of on to) is recorded from the early 18th century and has been widely used ever since. In US English, it is the regular form, although it is not wholly accepted in British English. Nevertheless, it is important to maintain a distinction between the preposition onto or on to and the use of the adverb on followed by the preposition to: she climbed onto (sometimes on to) the roof, but let's go on to (never onto) the next chapter

definitions: moving to a location on the surface of

examples.text: they went up onto the ridge

shortDefinitions: moving to location on surface of

definitions: moving aboard (a public conveyance) with the intention of traveling in it
shortDefinitions: moving aboard public service vehicle with intention of travelling in it
